author: Jack Williams
title: See inside volcano after snappers go 400ft deep to capture kaleidoscope of colours
text:
Ever wondered what it's like to descend 400ft to the pit of a mammoth dormant volcano and gaze upwards?
Wonder no more, because photographers have done just that.
And it's allowed them to produce a series of stunning artistic pictures .
Snappers went to the very base of Thrihnukagigur Volcano in Iceland to capture its kaleidoscope of colours.
So it's probably a good job that it hasn't erupted for more than 4,000 years.
K. MAACK / CATERS NEWS Arduous task: Adventurers must first hike around two miles to reach the volcano
K. MAACK / CATERS NEWS Descent snaps: Photographers enter the pit through a 12ft opening
Based 25 minutes from Reykjavik, Thrihnukagigur is so large the Statue of Liberty could fit inside.
Once the lensmen reached its base, they were able to look up in awe at the sheer scale of the colourful, shimmering rock structure above.
The expedition was part of a tour overseen by Inside Volcano, a company who have advertised it as 'a journey towards the centre of the Earth'.
In order to reach the volcano , adventurers must first hike around two miles, before entering the pit through a 12ft opening.
K. MAACK / CATERS NEWS Going down: The snappers are lowered into one of the volcano's magma chambers
K. MAACK / CATERS NEWS Shimmering: Once inside the volcano, people can take snaps of the stunning rock structure
K. MAACK / CATERS NEWS Dormant: Situated 25 minutes from Reykjavik, Thrihnukagigur has not erupted for more than 4,000 years
They are then lowered 400ft into one of the volcano's three magma chambers using a custom-made window-cleaning lift.
Once inside the volcano, people can then take photographs of the stunning surroundings.
Volcanic passages within the volcano continue down to a total depth of around 70ft.
In total, the whole experience lasts between five and six hours and costs $300 (Â£198) per person.
One of the photographers said: "The size and the colours make the experience so special.
K. MAACK / CATERS NEWS Adventure: The expedition is run by Inside Volcano
K. MAACK / CATERS NEWS Wow factor: The volcano's rock structure offers a kaleidoscope of colours
"People think about the fact they are standing 120-metres-deep inside a volcano and it gives them a sense of how small they really are.
"The first thing people usually do when they get into the volcano is look up."
